Cyt enables
Import in the .fcs \(default, standard flow-cytometry format) as well as .csv format.

Import from the .csv format,
Change file

Running viSNE and post-processing in cyt
Select the samples and measurements that you want analyzed by choosing the appropriate Gates and Channels in cyt.
Right-click on the selected ones and
Run viSNE \(bh-SNE).
Once the algorithm is finished, new channels, named bh-SNE1 and bh-SNE2, appear.
These are the SNE coordinates used for visualization of the data.
Visualize viSNE maps as scatter plots \(
Select bh-SNE1 and bh-SNE2 channels and click scatterplot), and play with the visualization options.
6. Categorize visual clusters into subpopulations, based on expert knowledge and optical and autofluorescent properties.
For example, by comparing the optical scatter and fluorescence intensities at different wavelengths it is possible to assign a category \(e.g.
cells with low forward scatter and high 660 nm intensity is likely to consist of cyanobacteria).
For quantification, the identified subpopulations need to be delineated, using the polygonal region selection tool in cyt.
Counting the number of particles/cells in each delineated region is done automatically by cyt.
Post-processing in Matlab
The analysis can be exported from cyt into Matlab by saving the session in cyt and then loading the session .mat
file into Matlab prompt.
To
Calculate the similarity between different viSNE maps, you can use maximum mean discrepancy as described in the file mmd_visne.m \(https://github.com/anzezupanic/FC_analysis ).
The compared maps should be of equal number of cells, and obtained from the analysis of the same parameters obtained from the same instrument.
To
See where particles/cells NOT used during viSNE would be projected onto a viSNE map, use the script in overlay_visne.m \(https://github.com/anzezupanic/FC_analysis ).
